docs.snippet: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 24 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that in the two years since the availability of certain radioactive isotopes for foreign distribution was announced by President Truman, 616 shipments had been made to...
docs.lead_paragraph: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 24 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that in the two years since the availability of certain radioactive isotopes for foreign distribution was announced by President Truman, 616 shipments had been made to twenty-two countries for use in medical and scientific research.
docs.abstract: Radio-strontium used for research on mosquito carrier, Brit W Africa

headline.main: ATOMIC MATERIALS GO TO 22 COUNTRIES; 616 Shipments of Isotopes Sent in 2 Years to Aid Medical and Scientific Research

docs.snippet: Last week's foreign exchange market was shaken to depths not plumbed in the international monetary history of this generation.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week's foreign exchange market was shaken to depths not plumbed in the international monetary history of this generation.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended Sept. 23, 1949.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, designed to harmonize international trade relations in the cause of world peace and prosperity, became law today and President Truman hailed it as a reaffirmation of our...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, designed to harmonize international trade relations in the cause of world peace and prosperity, became law today and President Truman hailed it as a reaffirmation of our live-and-let-live policy.
docs.abstract: Pres Truman holds Reciprocal Trade Act extension reaffirms US intention of pressing for expansion and for barriers end

headline.main: WORLD TRADE BILL SIGNED BY TRUMAN; Hull on Hand as the President Hails Extension Act, Calling Imports Our Responsibility

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Wilson H. Compton, alternate United States representative to the United Nations General Assembly, cautioned the Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today against attaching "undue significance" to "conflicts of...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Wilson H. Compton, alternate United States representative to the United Nations General Assembly, cautioned the Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today against attaching "undue significance" to "conflicts of opinion" over proposed legislation to carry out President Truman's Point Four program.
docs.abstract: W H Compton (US) reassures UN com on legis to carry out plan, reply to M A Zayed (Egypt); internatl action to back private capital use urged by NZ, Brazil and Uruguay reprs

headline.main: U. S. TRIES TO ALLAY FEARS ON POINT 4; Compton Urges U. N. Assembly Unit Not to Overrate Debate Here on Truman Hope

byline.original: By WILL LISSNERSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The Legal Committee voted today to open and close the annual General Assembly with one minute of silence dedicated to prayer or meditation, leaving it up to each delegate to use that time to pay homage to his God, meditate...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The Legal Committee voted today to open and close the annual General Assembly with one minute of silence dedicated to prayer or meditation, leaving it up to each delegate to use that time to pay homage to his God, meditate on the principles of the United Nations, or both.
docs.abstract: UN Legal Com votes 1 min of silence for prayer at UN Assembly 1st and last sessions

headline.main: U. N. Committee Backs Silent Prayer Proposal

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: The foreign exchange market was considerably less active than during the previous week. Though a large amount of transactions were reported at the start, as the week wore on the market settled down and only a moderate turnover took place.
docs.lead_paragraph: The foreign exchange market was considerably less active than during the previous week. Though a large amount of transactions were reported at the start, as the week wore on the market settled down and only a moderate turnover took place.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended Sept. 30, 1949.

docs.snippet: Devaluation of the Argentine peso will touch off a series of similar moves by other Latin-American countries, in the opinion of foreign exchange specialists here. They said yesterday that the action would cause, in South and Central America, the same...
docs.lead_paragraph: Devaluation of the Argentine peso will touch off a series of similar moves by other Latin-American countries, in the opinion of foreign exchange specialists here. They said yesterday that the action would cause, in South and Central America, the same reactions that the recent devaluation of the British pound had caused on a global scale.
docs.abstract: peso devalued 46% in relation to US dollar; 9-1 new rate; sliding scale set; banks resume exch deals; Brit Treas silent; other Latin-Amer nations seen following suit; NY reaction

docs.snippet: The application of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., for an operating differential subsidy for its three "Good Neighbor" passenger vessels was unopposed yesterday at a one-day hearing in Washington, the Maritime Commission's offices here reported.
docs.lead_paragraph: The application of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., for an operating differential subsidy for its three "Good Neighbor" passenger vessels was unopposed yesterday at a one-day hearing in Washington, the Maritime Commission's offices here reported.
docs.abstract: Moore-McCormack plea for operating subsidy on NYC-S Amer route unopposed

headline.main: LINE IS UNOPPOSED IN BID FOR SUBSIDY; Moore-McCormack Application for Aid on 'Good Neighbor' Service Heard by U. S.
